3589: Anvil of Bogardan.author: DarthParallax
3589: Anvil of Bogardan.text_parsed:
From the comments, I understand that this somehow used to beat Necropotence, but doesn't anymore becaue of errata?

Is it because this was errata'd, or because Necropotence was errata'd? I like 'old, irrelevant' history like this, so I'm curious, even if I can't use it like that for real.

I'm also a designer of Original cards in MSE, and I was thinking if this used to stop Necropotence, is there a way to push that old interaction a bit farther, increase some mana costs, possibly increase some life costs, and just maybe make a FAIR Necropotence if it has the right artifact made alongside it?

(I'm partial to making Necropotence . Any higher than 5cmc for this kind of thing and either you are making a card that won't be played, or you are printing an effect that isn't right at any cost. 'Fixed' Necropotence should cost a bit more than Phyrexian Obliterator. Yeah that sounds right.)

3589: Anvil of Bogardan.author: Ferlord
3589: Anvil of Bogardan.text_parsed:
So, here's what I understand with these "You have no maximum hand size" cards:

Some of them are some kind of book or book-related item (Spellbook, Venser's Journal, Library of Leng, Minamo Scrollkeeper). The idea is that you can't remember more than 7 spells from your library, so you store some of that excess memory in or onto a book. That makes sense.

And then there's this. Some kind of machination. Sense: this makes.

3589: Anvil of Bogardan.author: AeroSigma
3589: Anvil of Bogardan.text_parsed:
DarthParallax: Necopotence as printed gave you the extra cards during your discard step; as printed, this card makes everyone skip the discard step, so they would never be able to get the cards from necropotence. Both of them have been errata'd to get rid of the discard step requirement.

If you want to un-break Necropotence, I'd recommend limiting the number of times the ability can be used, in addition to upping the life payment. For example, "everytime you play this ability after the first in turn, discard a card."
3589: Anvil of Bogardan.text_posted:
DarthParallax: Necopotence as printed gave you the extra cards during your discard step; as printed, this card makes everyone skip the discard step, so they would never be able to get the cards from necropotence. Both of them have been errata'd to get rid of the discard step requirement.

If you want to un-break Necropotence, I'd recommend limiting the number of times the ability can be used, in addition to  upping the life payment.  For example, "everytime you play this ability after the first in turn, discard a card."

3591: Diamond Kaleidoscope.author: graey24601
3591: Diamond Kaleidoscope.text_parsed:
In casual this thing is a lot more powerful than people give it credit for. Toss some mana at it here and there, nobody much cares that you're creating 0/1 creatures. Who's going to waste resources killing them? Nobody. Who's going to wish they had when you sac them to call down a massive, board clearing Comet Storm or similar? Everyone, but then it's too late.
Of course there's the obvious Lord of the Pit and similar upkeep handling and popping out a blocker at instant speed. One facet that is often missed is that the sacrifice for mana does not tap anything, so if you have a couple tokens in play even with all your permanents tapped your opponents have to assume that you can still cast.

3595: Juju Bubble.author: longwinded
3595: Juju Bubble.text_parsed:
Now I can at least appreciate it as an interesting design experiment, but back when Visions came out, I obviously hated pulling this card. A 2:1 mana:life gain ratio was about right for the times for artifacts (see Fountain of Life), or 1:1 with some restrictions (the lucky charms cycle, Soul Net, Urza's Chalice). With those costs in mind, this card is basically a multi-turn Stream of Life: you can keep pumping mana into this card, without triggers or limit, again and again, so long as you don't stop to spend the mana on something else (at least not a spell). The cumulative upkeep is there to guarantee diminishing returns, so you don't just play this after you've established board dominance, automatically gain 5 life each turn, and have an insurmountable lead by the time you actually have to cast a spell.

It's more like a "long sorcery" than a true, reusable permanent. In conjunction with the right activated abilities (such as Daring Apprentice's ability to counter an opponent's worst spells), it might be playable to some advantage.

3595: Juju Bubble.author: dberry02
3595: Juju Bubble.text_parsed:
Eww, it isn't even errata'ed to cast.

"When you play a card, sacrifice Juju Bubble."

For those of you who arn't adept at the m10 rules change, it means this:
Spells you cast from your hand are considered cast.
Lands you drop on the battlefield are considered to be played.
When the wording was changed, all spells that you normally played from your hand, are now cast from your hand instead.

Some cards like Juju Bubble have kept their wording as played. That means, that if you cast a spell OR play a land for the turn, it is considered as playing that card. So essentially, when you cast a spell or play a land for your turn, it triggers this card's sacrifice ability.

If you don't believe me on the "play" wording, just look at Future Sight, another card that kept it's same wording. It had to keep the origional wording or else you wouldn't be able to play lands off the top of your library (because you don't cast lands - you play them.)

In conclusion, this card is terrible. 0.5/5
3595: Juju Bubble.text_posted:
Eww, it isn't even errata'ed to [i]cast[/i].

[i]"When you play a card, sacrifice Juju Bubble."[/i]

For those of you who arn't adept at the m10 rules change, it means this:
Spells you cast from your hand are considered [i][b]cast[/b][/i].
Lands you drop on the battlefield are considered to be [i][b]played[/b][/i].
When the wording was changed, all spells that you normally [i]played[/i] from your hand, are now [i]cast[/i] from your hand instead.

Some cards like [autocard]Juju Bubble[/autocard] have kept their wording as played. That means, that if you [i]cast[/i] a spell [u]OR[/u] [i]play[/i] a land for the turn, it is considered as [i]playing that card[/i]. So essentially, when you cast a spell or play a land for your turn, it triggers this card's sacrifice ability.

If you don't believe me on the "play" wording, just look at [autocard]Future Sight[/autocard], another card that kept it's same wording. It had to keep the origional wording or else you wouldn't be able to play lands off the top of your library (because you don't cast lands - you play them.)

In conclusion, this card is terrible. 0.5/5

3597: Magma Mine.author: Lyoncet
3597: Magma Mine.text_parsed:
While this card is certainly not stellar by any means, it does have one very useful application: in an artifact-focused deck, it can serve as an alternate win condition between the ease of producing colorless mana and its ability to be searched with Trinket Mage. Of course, there are much better win conditions for such a deck between Steel Overseer, Master of Etherium, Chimeric Mass, etc., but against a deck with lots of things like creature removal/Runed Halos/Pithing Needles/Meddling Mages/Phyrexian Negators/Linvala, Keeper of Silence, having one or two of these in your sideboard can really serve to keep your kills from being completely shut down.

Plus, if you're running an infinite mana loop like Grim Monolith/Power Artifact, this could be a turn 3 win (turn 2 if you can swing 2 colorless mana on turn 1) that your opponent would likely not see coming and therefore be unlikely to counteract in time. This is as opposed to Chimeric Mass, which has to wait a turn to overcome summoning sickness unless you have a way of granting it haste (but otherwise is much more solid). Still can't really rate this above a 3 since it's applications are limited, but it serves its purpose.

3598: Matopi Golem.author: longwinded
3598: Matopi Golem.text_parsed: This is one of those experimental mechanics that just wasn't as powerful or popular as they would have hoped, at least not for the cost. It's a variation on the self-withering creatures like Rock Hydra/Balduvian Hydra that had been previously printed: you couldn't increase the power of this guy beyond baseline, but you also didn't have to let him wither unless he was going to be destroyed. If either the regeneration or the golem himself were just {1} cheaper, this would be a better card.

3600: Phyrexian Walker.author: The_Stray
3600: Phyrexian Walker.text_parsed:
InQuest magazine rated this as the worst card in Visions. This was the same magazine that rated Dream Halls the worst card in Stronghold.

Unlike the Dream Halls debacle this time they had an excuse for not realizing this card's potential. At the time this was printed there weren't a lot of cards that cared about artifacts, and equipment didn't exist, so they can be forgiven for not seeing the power of a 0 CMC critter right off the bat. They were all like "It's worse than Ornithopter because it doesn't fly!"

Fast forward to Urza's Saga, Tolarian Academy, and suddenly we all learned the power of 0 cost artifacts. Then came Mirroden...and now what was once considered the epitome of crap is getting 4-star ratings. How the times have changed.

3600: Phyrexian Walker.author: Aquillion
3600: Phyrexian Walker.text_parsed:
This card is basically an object lesson in how important environment is to a card's power level.

At the time it was printed, it was a mildly interesting but mostly useless curiosity.

Then came Tolarian Academy, Tinker, and Goblin Welder, and it was nice to have around as a defense that could fuel those cards; but still nothing amazing.

Then we got Affinity decks and Steel Overseer and Tempered Steel, and now in the right deck this is basically a mox that can also block for you early on and become a beatstick later.

3601: Sands of Time.author: LG
3601: Sands of Time.text_parsed:
Fictionarious, the revised Oracle text says "at the beginning of the upkeep", and the untap step doesn't exist. Each turn begins with the beginning of the upkeep (unless it ceases to exist too: Eon Hub), but it's irrelevant to my question: does a Sands of Time that comes into play "at the beginning of the upkeep" (e.g. via Braids, Conjurer Adept) trigger in the same upkeep or only on the next turn's upkeep?
The rules aren't very clear on "the beginning of the upkeep" being a state (a piece of the upkeep) or an event (the transition between whatever comes before, either the draw step or the previous turn or something else, and the upkeep).

My favorite combinations are with Capsize (beyond one Capsize per turn, and it's easy to play 2-3, it's usually game over), Prodigal Sorcerer/Zuran Spellcaster/Reveka, Wizard Savant etc. for creature extermination and burn, with Betrayal etc. and Psychic Venom etc. to abuse the opponent's permanents, Archivist/Arcanis the Omnipotent etc. to draw. Never got around to try Equipoise.

3601: Sands of Time.author: MTGFreak
3601: Sands of Time.text_parsed:
I can only say this:

Since it's YOUR turn you have priority. So, when multiple cards have effects in the same phases you can pick what happens. Artifacts don't have summoning sickness (unless their Artifact creatures)

So, yes. A Sands of Time coming into play with an effect or ability will trigger as long as their being done in the same phase.

1. Sands of Time (already in play)
2. Untap phase is skipped
3. Beginning of your upkeep, Braids ability triggers
4. Sands of Time that is reveled from Braids hits play and still in your beginning of your Upkeep phase
5. 2nd Sands of Time triggers.

If I have it right that is. I'm 90% sure it's the proper way.

3601: Sands of Time.author: Ragamander
3601: Sands of Time.text_parsed:
+ Eon Hub = no more untapping. Add Kismet/Frozen Aether for lock-down. Then you just wait to draw lands and play your win condition (something with vigilance would be fairly effective).

Oh, @LG: It would not trigger. "At the beginning of your upkeep" is an event.

@MTGFreak: No, it does not trigger after being put into play at the beginning of your upkeep. At the beginning of the upkeep step, all things that trigger at the beginning of your upkeep go onto the stack. If something comes into play after all those triggered abilities go onto the stack, then it has come into play after the only "at the beginning of your upkeep" trigger, and therefore it will not trigger. Of course, there's always Paradox Haze. Heheh, that would be so confusing. And it would make Capsize truly horrifying...

3601: Sands of Time.author: GrimjawxRULES
3601: Sands of Time.text_parsed:
@LG: When you put Sands of Time onto the battlefield with Braids at the beginning of the upkeep, that event has already passed. When it becomes "the beginning of the upkeep", the game checks for all cards in play that trigger abilities, and these abilities then go on the stack to resolve in whatever order. When Braids's ability resolves and Sands of Time enters the battlefield, the game has already checked for abilities that trigger at this time, Sands of Time's triggered ability won't trigger, because the event (the beginning of the upkeep" has already passed.

TL;DR - permanents entering the battlefield during your upkeep won't trigger their "at the beginning of upkeep" abilities, because it's already too late at that point.

Also, just a reminder: you can't play cards or activate abilities on a turn before the "beginning of the upkeep" event has triggered This is because no players get priority before this event. The Leylines and Gemstone Cavern could be called an exception to this, but that's because you get to start the game with them in play before you actually get your turn.

3601: Sands of Time.author: Aquillion
3601: Sands of Time.text_parsed:
The removal of mana burn substantially weakens this card, because your opponent can just tap all their lands to ensure they always untap. (You can do the same, but it means the card has less impact.) Also, this weakens the Paradox Haze combo -- your opponent can tap all their lands in response to the effect going off the second time, meaning all their lands will always untap. In fact, this even lets them do instant-speed stuff with the extra mana.

It does lock down their creatures and artifacts, but only the stuff with no tap abilities.

3601: Sands of Time.author: SkyMureaux
3601: Sands of Time.text_parsed:
@LG.

You are wrong.

>Comprehensive Rules. Updated April 2013
Section 502 and subsections used.
>Untap step gives no priority
>Occurs before ANY beginning of upkeep effects.
>HOWEVER, given any effect that occurs in the untap step, you can respond to it. Just like in the upkeep, you CANNOT respond to it as you do not have priority unless an effect triggers. (Re: Mesmeric Orb allows you to respond in the untap step, pre-upkeep, provided SOMETHING exists to untap)

I suggest you reread your rules. The untap DOES exist. Just because oracle changes a card doesn't change gameplay entirely. (Re: Guardian Beast. The effect was massively changed as temporary effects + untapping him used to create an entirely different effect than what he does now, many cards are 'improved' by oracle or change functionality entirely)

@MTGFreak

When a phase begins, it checks all permanents and triggers them all at once. This trigger only occurs once.

Example:

>Upkeep trigger
>Sands of Time A Triggers
>Braids Triggers
>Braids Resolves, places new Sands of Time B onto the field
>Sands of Time A Resolves

There is no new upkeep trigger to set off Sands of Time B. So it will not act until the next upkeep.

@Guest1381794618

They 'stack' in the terms of 2 Sands of Time would tap and untap, and untap and tap (depending on orientation of said cards) all permanents. 3 would replicate the effect of 1, and 4 the effect of 2, and so on.

Though it would trigger when a creature taps or untaps effects properly, yes. IE the Mesmeric Orb I mentioned above.

@tavaritz & Paladin85

Stasis how? Stasis prevents anything from becoming untapped. 2 of these will just return the field to its proper position every turn. Just tapping and untapping everything. Which honestly could yield some nice instant / mana dump mana (it triggers the tapping, tap in response, thusly it untaps it, 2nd triggers, tap it in response to have it freely untapped)

But not so much stasis, unless you combo it with something else I am not seeing you post.

3601: Sands of Time.author: Xycolian
3601: Sands of Time.text_parsed:
Surprised nobody's mentioned this yet, but it effectively doubles your mana pool for instant/flash cards, or cards with abilities such as Helix pinnacle.

Don't tap any of your lands for a turn, pass over to your opponent, and then when it's your turn again, and this goes on the stack, tap all of your mana producers in response to it, and then let it resolve. This will untap the lands you just tapped, and now you can tap them again.

For example, if you play this on turn 4 with 4 lands, you can cast up to 10 mana worth of instants on the beginning turn 6 with no ramp whatsoever.

If you plan on using this kind of strategy though, you're bound to have ramp... because it can utilize things like Mana vault, Grim monolith and Basalt Monolith without their usual drawbacks. Doubling cube is also a nice ramp card with this combo.

Throw in a Leyline of anticipation, and you effectively double your mana, but only during your upkeep. It also makes passing your turn safer, because you can answer threats instantly. Throw in mana fixing cards like Chromatic lantern, or Mycosynth Lattice, and you can cast any card you want. Ultimatums are pretty fun.
3601: Sands of Time.text_posted:
Surprised nobody's mentioned this yet, but it effectively doubles your mana pool for instant/flash cards, or cards with abilities such as [autocard]Helix pinnacle[/autocard].

Don't tap any of your lands for a turn, pass over to your opponent, and then when it's your turn again, and this goes on the stack, tap all of your mana producers in response to it, and then let it resolve. This will untap the lands you just tapped, and now you can tap them again.

For example, if you play this on turn 4 with 4 lands, you can cast up to 10 mana worth of instants on the beginning turn 6 with [i]no ramp[/i] whatsoever.

If you plan on using this kind of strategy though, you're bound to have ramp... because it can utilize things like [autocard]Mana vault[/autocard], [autocard]Grim monolith[/autocard] and [autocard]Basalt Monolith[/autocard] without their usual drawbacks. [autocard]Doubling cube[/autocard] is also a nice ramp card with this combo.

Throw in a [autocard]Leyline of anticipation[/autocard], and you effectively double your mana, but only during your upkeep. It also makes passing your turn safer, because you can answer threats instantly. Throw in mana fixing cards like [autocard]Chromatic lantern[/autocard], or [autocard]Mycosynth Lattice[/autocard], and you can cast any card you want. Ultimatums are pretty fun.

3604: Teferi's Puzzle Box.author: PolskiSuzeren
3604: Teferi's Puzzle Box.text_parsed:
Drawing a card isn't a trigger, it's just an action that's taken. Other than that, tavaritz is right on the spot. You draw your card before anything in the phase happens, then all triggers that would apply are put on the stack.


If it said "at the end of the draw step" then it'd trigger when you went to leave the draw step. for the most part, it'd be the same, but other "at the beginning of your draw step" triggers wouldn't be stackable with this to get an advantage, such as Maralen of the mornsong.

3609: Blanket of Night.author: Necrokeryx
3609: Blanket of Night.text_parsed:
I prefer Urborg, Tomb of Yawgmoth for three reasons:

#1 It's a land, so it can be used on the very first turn and counts itself as a swamp.
#2 It leaves more space for nonland cards that will win you the game.
#3 Lands are generally harder to destroy than enchantments. This isn't always the case, but usually.

Still, it's a good card. I used to use this with Zombie Master until I found Urborg.

3609: Blanket of Night.author: Max_Glycine
3609: Blanket of Night.text_parsed: I understand that the oracle ruling is supposed to make things simpler, and the oracle text doesn't include the mana-producing clause, but considering that the original text is "each mana-producing land," isn't the ruling "10/4/2004 It can affect lands which do not produce mana" kind of counter-intuitive? Last I checked, oracle rulings weren't actually supposed to change the execution of the card, just fine-tune it.
3609: Blanket of Night.text_posted: I understand that the oracle ruling is supposed to make things simpler, and the oracle text doesn't include the mana-producing clause, but considering that the original text is "each mana-producing land," isn't the ruling "10/4/2004 It can affect lands which do not produce mana" kind of counter-intuitive? 3609: Blanket of Night.author: Kurraga
3609: Blanket of Night.text_parsed:
@Max_Glycine
Pretty much, this card should probably read "Each land with a mana ability is a swamp in addition to it's other types", not to balance it (Urborg, Tomb of Yawgmoth is a much better alternative, and is fine), but because it most closely matches its lates (and only, accoring to this) official printing.

If you look around gatherer there are plenty of cards where they jumped through rules/semantics hoops to keep the cards funcionally the same.

3610: Brood of Cockroaches.author: Paolino
3610: Brood of Cockroaches.text_parsed:
Very very flavorful.
The artwork on this card is really great; I miss these artwork, which were DRAWN, and not made with computer graphics. I'm not saying that modern artworks are bad, of course; I'm just saying that nowadays artworks are always very detailed, but sometimes these old simple drawings have more expressiveness than a very detailed artwork, due to their "at-first-glance-impression" effect.
Concerning the card, it is very particular and it's the perfect chump-blocker. As for the ability itself, I see combo with Nether Traitor (and some other combos involving it) and Field of Souls...

3612: Crypt Rats.author: NV.Collis
3612: Crypt Rats.text_parsed:
Crypt Rats is a great card in a deck able to tap most lands for black mana. So long as you make a deck that can fit it, and come on.... what else is black good at if not building a deck that can get your creatures back from the great beyond faster that your non black opponent (or make use of the poor souls lost to Crypt Rats furry)?

Good decks are full of biffy creatures and high cost cards (I'm over exaggerating to make a point here... don't go ape crazy on me!), great decks take a card like Crypt Rats and build around it.

I, in a humble attempt tried to do just this.

Its a combo deck based off Crypt Rats equipped with Scythe of the Wretched while having a mana creature on the field (ie Blood Vassal) and a life gaining creature (I use a Dross Harvester... for personal taste reasons) and now your off to infinite fun... well not infinite fun as the combo is infinite but your opponents life totals aren't....

And If you have a hard time playing off the combo due to Crypt Rats getting hated by all the other players, fear not! Thats why you add a Necrotic Ooze to the mix and a Will-o'-the-Wisp in your graveyard for good measure.

Any ways heres a link to my 'Wretched Rats' deck for your viewing pleasure! Leave comments if you like it, change it to work for you and have fun in multi-player casual games!

http://www.essentialmagic.com//Decks/View.asp?ID=830159

Cheers NV!

3620: Kaervek's Spite.author: ArashikageClan
3620: Kaervek's Spite.text_parsed:
I don't know why this is rated so low, the effect is really quite good as a finisher. And it's not like you can't float mana, resolve this, and cast more, not that I would ever do that since this should be a finisher period. I mean, 1/4th of your life total is hardly anything to sneeze at, especially when it's lose life not take 5 damage, at instant speed even.

Try it in a Suicide Black deck sometime and you'll see what I'm talking about. And as for it getting countered, that's why it would be in Suicide Black, so you can protect it with Duress or Thoughtseize.

3620: Kaervek's Spite.author: Mode
3620: Kaervek's Spite.text_parsed:
At first one might think this is completely unplayable - I also did.

I still think only one part of the additional cost - either discarding your hand or sacrificing all permanents you control - should have done as well at a mana cost of for a lifeloss of 5, but Wizards possibly made both since you could otherwise bring a Swamp, Dark Ritual and this on turn one.
Yet that insanity of additional cost can also be used for your advantage:
*If you can get your opponent to copy the effect. Currently Hive Mind seems to be the only card available, although using Pacts with it is more advisable most of the time...
*Try to protect your cards by exiling them for a period of time, e.g. with flicker effects (which return the cards at end of turn) or by using cards with phasing.
*Use cards which trigger when put into the graveyard like Flagstones of Trokair, and play it as response on cards like Balancing Act.
Those which deal damage or will get you permanents onto the battlefield other than from your hand are likely the best cards for this. Academy Rector in particular is likely the best choice when used to find a Barren Glory, since you can Kaervek's Spite at the end of an opponent's turn resulting in an instant win once you get to your upkeep if your opponent does not have any removal left.

3620: Kaervek's Spite.author: Zielheim
3620: Kaervek's Spite.text_parsed:
@Necrokeryx

How would that work exactly? The moment you cast Bitter Ordeal it would try to copy itself thanks to gravestorm, you can't cast that then this and go nuts on their library, the moment would pass. You'd have to have something like Sign in Blood or Moriok Replica, cast/activate it, then drop this, then hope that you draw into Bitter Ordeal with the next two/four cards, and that's if you have enough mana to pull that off (which would total 8 mana, possibly 10 if you have sign in blood + the replica, or just two of the replica). I suppose it COULD work if you had something that rearranged the top cards of your library, but that's about it, AND you'd have to wait until Bitter Ordeal showed up before going off with the combo, which could easily be disrupted.

There's not much use for this card, unless you're in a situation where your field is little-to-none with your hand being the same, or as a way to get rid of the Persecutor. Even the prospect of finishing them off with it isn't that good since odds are you can just deal that remaining 5 points to them in some other fashion WITHOUT having to get rid of everything, just in case it turns out they have something that leaves you screwed (like a sudden life gain, or a redirection to you, or flat-out cancel it).

3621: Necromancy.author: adrian.malacoda
3621: Necromancy.text_parsed:
@TheKazu: The strange wording for that effect is because when Necromancy ETB, it puts a triggered ability on the stack. When that triggered ability resolves, it may or may not actually still be on the battlefield (for example, if you responded to the ability by bouncing the enchantment). This is sort of a reverse situation of the Fiend Hunter/Oblivion Ring trick that involves flickering or bouncing the Fiend Hunter/Oblivion Ring in response to its ETB trigger. The net effect of doing so is that its LTB ability actually happens BEFORE the ETB one does, causing the target to be permanently removed.

In Necromancy's case, were it not for the "if it's on the battlefield" clause, you could cast Necromancy and then bounce it in response to the ETB. The LTB goes on the stack, resolves, and does nothing (since you have not reanimated anything yet) and then the ETB resolves and you get to permanently reanimate a creature (This also conveniently sidesteps the disadvantage to casting this at instant speed, consequently).

3621: Necromancy.author: Leshrac_Nightwalker
3621: Necromancy.text_parsed:
@heenaheena: Actually, if the card was errataed to have Flash, it wouldn't play the same.

This thing is part of a cycle of enchantments from Visions (Mystic Veil, Parapet, Relic Ward and Spider Climb) that were designed to be modal - more versatile. You have two options with any of these cards:

->Play the card "at sorcery speed" - you're playing the enchantment as an enchantment. You get the card's intended effect, and it sticks around until it is destroyed or the permanent it is attached to is destroyed.
->Play the card "at instant speed" - you get the effect at instant speed, but it is only good until the end of turn. If you play one of these as an instant, you have to sacrifice it at the end of the current turn.

With these enchantments, you could opt to play them as normal enchantments, with the same timing restrictions, OR you could opt to play them as nasty surprises for your opponent - say, using Mystic Veil to effectively counter a Terror, or using Necromancy here to sneak a surprise blocker into play. If you choose to go for the "Gotcha!" option, they are only meant to last until the end of the turn.

Think of them as cards that you can either play as an enchantment or as an instant, and hopefully the convoluted wording will make more sense.

EDIT: I realize that you may not have needed all that... I guess my point is really just that "You may play this as though it had flash" is not its own line on the card - it's part of the "if you cast this spell at any time that you couldn't have cast a sorcery" rule, and I think it's supposed to provide clarity. Functionally, though, I do see your point, and one of the only differences (as far as I can tell) is that as worded now, the cards in this cycle can't be fetched with Mystical Teachings.

EDIT EDIT: @heenaheena - Your wording would be less wordy, but it would also make for some very strange interactions with other cards that allow you to cast spells as though they had flash (Vedalken Orrery, Leyline of Anticipation, Alchemist's Refuge). As written, Necromancy could be cast at instant speed like any other nonland permanent in your deck; with your version, none of the three cards I've linked above would actually provide any benefit to Necromancy.

3621: Necromancy.author: heenaheena
3621: Necromancy.text_parsed:
I'd been ignoring this card for a while in favor of the cheaper mana-cost alternatives animate dead and dance of the dead but I'm going to give this one a try and I think in the long run it will be better than dance of the dead which is kinda clunky.

on another note, the Oracle says this card may be cast as though it had flash. Flash is the ability to be cast any time an instant could be cast. so Necromancy may be cast as though it had the ability to be cast any time an instant could be cast? Why not just give it flash?

EDIT:
@Leshrac_Nightstalker
the top portion of the card could simply read:

Flash
If you cast Necromancy any time a sorcery couldn't have been cast, the controller of the permanent it becomes sacrifices it at the beginning of the next cleanup step.

All the cards in this cycle should, imho, be errata'd this way. They would still play the same but, yes, other cards that care about whether or not they have flash (which is extremely few) would interact differently with them... but so what? In fact, these cards (like mystical teachings, as you mentioned) should interact with Necromancy because Necromancy actually DOES have flash when you think about it. Flash says: "You may cast this spell any time you could cast an instant." Can you cast Necromancy any time you could cast an instant? yes.

EDIT: EDIT:
@Leshrac_Nightstalker
yea, i guess you're right about vedalken orrery and whatnot.

Forgetting about the flash ability for a moment, I think that the whole reanimation ability would be a lot less wordy if it didn't make Necromancy an Aura (I know that Wizards isn't going to ever errata this card that significantly; I'm mainly just giving an idea for a new card). Here is the reanimation ability (for a normal enchantment):


When CARDNAME enters the battlefield, put target creature card from a graveyard onto the battlefield under your control. When either card leaves the battlefield, the other's controller sacrifices it.


I am aware that this wording has some flaws (for example, you can sac CARDNAME in response to the triggered ability to permanently reanimate a creature), and the wording might not be completely correct, but I think it's a good idea.

It's 4 mana for either destroying a creature or dealing 5 damage to an opponent. Because the opponent has to sacrifice a creature and doesn't target anything, it gets around protection, shroud, invulnerability, damage prevention, and so forth. If they don't sac a creature, then they take 5 unpreventable damage (unless they play an instant or have something that prevents them from losing life). It's a pretty decent card.

3624: Pillar Tombs of Aku.author: Taudisban
3624: Pillar Tombs of Aku.text_parsed:
I had a friend that used this in a creature-less deck. It almost always backfired.

Also: Aku is a floating fortress city in the Uuserk Marshes, built by the mundungu, the alliance of Shadow Guild and Shaper Guild mages from Zhalfir. The city was constructed to hold the pillar tombs of Zhalfirin royalty, preventing them from being desecrated by grave-robbers. Thus, Aku was built in Uuserk, the most inhospitable region of Zhalfir. Its powerful mages and flesh-hungry djinn kept the demons of Kaervek away from it during the war, and were instrumental to his defeat. Kaervek was buried in one of the pillar tombs of Aku.

Aku has been phased out alongside the rest of northwestern Jamuraa since the planeswalker Teferi wanted to spare it from the horrors of the Phyrexian Invasion. It was removed from existence when Jeska destroyed the time rift over Zhalfir.


I was wondering who Aku was (I thought this was their tomb or something) and a gatherer search came up with EmrAKUl . I was gonna roll with that but lets be honest, Teferi is cooler than the Eldrazi.

3626: Suq'Ata Assassin.author: kitsunewarlock
3626: Suq'Ata Assassin.text_parsed:
Evasion and posion counters AND damage. Poison counters are still quite lame though. I LOVE them mechanically and have even built a deck around them. But only having 10 counters means you can't print cards that add more than 3 per swing without breaking them...they are hard to use when they only work with creatures. We need a planwalkers and instants and sorceries that can deal them as extra effects for doing stuff we already love like removal or burn.

If this guy was just a 2/2 evasion for 3 they'd be dead just by damage.
3626: Suq'Ata Assassin.text_posted:
Evasion and posion counters AND damage.  Poison counters are still quite lame though.  I LOVE them mechanically and have even built a deck around them.  But only having 10 counters means you can't print cards that add more than 3 per swing without breaking them...they are hard to use when they only work with creatures.  We need a planwalkers and instants and sorceries that can deal them as extra effects for doing stuff we already love like removal or burn.

3626: Suq'Ata Assassin.author: KrosanGardener
3626: Suq'Ata Assassin.text_parsed: That's the problem: a poison counter is basically just two damage. Sure, it negates life gain. But that's rarely a significant factor, because life gain is rarely good. When it is good, it's typically tacked on to other effects, (e.g. Kitchen Finks) and so the life gain is a small bonus.  Poison counters just aren't worth it, competitively.
3626: Suq'Ata Assassin.text_posted: That's the problem: a poison counter is basically just two damage. Sure, it negates life gain. 3632: Wicked Reward.author: BastianQoU
3632: Wicked Reward.text_parsed:
@Darth:
That there is why most players hate Infect. It's so easily abused that it takes no original thinking to come up with a strategy. Essentially, your opponents start with half their life, they can't gain life, and all pump spells do double duty.

That said, I never turn aside creature sacrifice without giving it a good thought over. It's always a nice way of taking care of creatures that might be getting out of hand (I'm looking at you, Ravenous Demon..), and there are plenty of ways to turn it into an advantage (Howdy, Anger). This is a quick and easy way to sac early, when your engine isn't running yet.

3633: Betrayal.author: DarthParallax
3633: Betrayal.text_parsed:
Is there a way that particularly strange ownership/control manipulating card interactions, like Zedruu the Greathearted plus Bazaar Trader plus Mindslaver might somehow allow you to control a creature enchanted with this? What if you somehow made it so that the opponent controlled BETRAYAL?

There must be something that exchanges control of an enchantment- from there, you should be able to use Mindslaver and/or some Donate effects in response to make it so that the opponent will then give you the creature you enchanted with this. Unless State-Based Actions take priority over everything on the stack?

Barring that, I guess Ophidian-effects aren't a lot worse. Generally you put them on creatures with evasion in the first place, so it comes out to the same thing.

3635: Chronatog.author: Kurraga

I disagree with the errata to make the skip a turn thing a part of the ability rather than a cost. It goes against the flavour of the card (he eats your next turn, then gets bigger. Not the strongest flavour, but it's there) and the "Make the cards do what say on the most tcent printing of the card in oracle" policy (except in the case of misprints, I think Walking Atlas has every right to be an artifact).

I can understand "skip your next turn as a cost is bad" as a design policy, but changes in policy shouldn't affect older cards.

3638: Dream Tides.author: Wizard-of-the-Toast
3638: Dream Tides.text_parsed: Underrated. Definitely a johnny card. In a W/U deck with vigilance creatures or Serra's Blessing this can cause big problems for any aggro opponent especially black and red due to their lack of enchantment removal. Mix in a painter's servant or other colour changer (or Rising Waters) and it can paralyse their creatures whatever their colour. Blue and White also have plenty of cards with which you can tap your opponent's creatures eg Blinding Light.

3638: Dream Tides.author: DacenOctavio
3638: Dream Tides.text_parsed:
If you got a way to return permanents back to your hand at instant speed, you could do it at the end of opponent's turns so you can be unaffected. :)

Aside from that, I run this card in Numot, the Devastator with Tamiyo, the Moon Sage and Dawnglare Invoker. Seeing how Splinter Twin is one of my primary win conditions, keeping my opponents short on mana or drawing fire from my best enchantment is a primary concern. This card is one you can just set and forget and it helps your control deck's strategy.

3643: Knight of the Mists.author: scumbling1
3643: Knight of the Mists.text_parsed:
This card was fun back when Visions was first printed. There were a lot of knights being played (especially in casual games), so killing someone else's knight was a surprisingly useful ability. As a small side-bonus, nothing trumps flanking like flanking.

I'm glad to see some other people appreciating Harold McNeill. Check out some of his non-Magic artwork while you're still online; it's fantastic.

3643: Knight of the Mists.author: reapersaurus
3643: Knight of the Mists.text_parsed:
scumbling1 -
I'd reconsider appreciating Harold McNeill, as an artist or person.
I met him in '95 at WotC's Artist's Caravan along with other Magic artists.
I expressed to him my enjoyment of his (I thought absurd) art for Invoke Prejudice. He lit up, and said I might be interested in some of his other art, then. He pulled out a couple artbooks filled with racist and Nazi-inspired art. Creeped out beyond belief, I sheepishly thanked him and got the hell away from that table as quick as I could.
There's a reason why he has done almost zero professional work for a long time.
His MySpace confirms he's a complete racist nutjob.

3645: Mystic Veil.author: tavaritz
3645: Mystic Veil.text_parsed:
It is kinda convoluted way to phrase the functionality, but given todays rules about auras it's quite understandable that it must be phrased like this.

You cannot use the old '...as an instant, if you do, bury it at the end of turn.' because instants are put to grave immediately after they have resolved.

Today when you cast an aura you target a permanent it can be attached to and when the aura resolves it becomes an enchantment enchanting that permanent. So you cannot refer to it as the aura when it is a permanent, but you must refer to it as the permanent it became to.

You cannot give it flash because there are other cards that refer cards havinng flash and that would then change this card's functinality.

So you say that it can be cast as though it has flash. Then the actual timing of the casting is used to define if it will be buried at the end of turn.

The existing rules are not very friendly to read, but they are very exact and clear on what they mean.

3647: Prosperity.author: Equinox523
3647: Prosperity.text_parsed:
Prosperity/Cadaverous Bloom was one of the most devastating decks of the time, because City of Solitude made this card, which seems fair because it is symmetrical card drawing, quite unfair. As with a lot of cards which are "fair", in context it really isn't: once the City is down, you are free to draw a ton of cards while your opponent sits idly as you get a flood of mana from cards you've drawn, converting them all to , and unleashing a game-ending Drain Life.

Without a combo, this is also a fine card in mill decks, and also a card that will get you friends in multiplayer games.
3647: Prosperity.text_posted:
[autocard]Prosperity[/autocard]/[autocard]Cadaverous Bloom[/autocard] was one of the most devastating decks of the time, because [autocard]City of Solitude[/autocard] made this card, which seems fair because it is symmetrical card drawing, quite unfair.  As with a lot of cards which are "fair", in context it really isn't: once the City is down, you are free to draw a ton of cards while your opponent sits idly as you get a flood of mana from cards you've drawn, converting them all to [B][B], and unleashing a game-ending [autocard]Drain Life[/autocard].

Without a combo, this is also a fine card in mill decks, and also a card that will get you friends in multiplayer games.

3648: Rainbow Efreet.author: Aquillion
3648: Rainbow Efreet.text_parsed:
As others said, this card was severely weakened in the M10 rules change; previously, you could let it deal damage, then phase it out before the damage it took killed it. Now you can't, so it's almost never going to be able to use that 3 power on a creature without dying.

In a pinch you can still use it to block and then phase it out before damage is dealt, though, and the creature it blocked will still be blocked.

Compare to Faerie Impostor. The Impostor is twice as strong, but can't bounce herself.

So if you just planned on using him to bounce another one of your creature, run the Impostor instead.

However, this Drake can still be interesting if you want to abuse his cip/etb trigger on itself to make use of the triggered ability of another permanent (see Shapter's list), or the Storm effect of some instant/sorcery,
or to accomplish other stuff done by casting plenty of spells in one turn, like getting Erayo flipped.

3651: Teferi's Realm.author: nirvava
3651: Teferi's Realm.text_parsed:
Part of one my favorite lockdown decks of all time.

This + Sands of Time, and nothing ever phased back in. Used Spatial Binding for spot phasing resistance (only use I ever found for that card) and Reality Ripple for cheap and permanent spot removal. Even if your opponent called 'artifacts' on his turn, everything wouldn't phase back in until your turn, preserving the lock. Also threw artifact mana producers and Chimeric Idol (doesn't become a creature til you activate it and costs zero mana to activate) to further discourage my opponent from calling out 'artifacts'.

Throw in a Chronotag, and just watch your opponent draw out.
3651: Teferi's Realm.text_posted:

Also threw artifact mana producers and [autocard]Chimeric Idol[/autocard] (doesn't become a creature til you activate it and costs zero mana to activate) to further discourage my opponent from calling out 'artifacts'.

3655: Vanishing.author: yyukichigai
3655: Vanishing.text_parsed:
Great card. Low casting cost, low effect cost. Works well on either your creatures (save your critters when they're targeted) or an opponent's (remove their creatures when they pose a risk). Good for combat situations too: even though you can't phase the creature out in response to normal damage anymore, you can still phase it out before damage step entirely, allowing you to block without risk of losing your creature (i.e. the Dream Fighter effect).

I used to use this a lot back in the day. Saved my tukhus on more than one occasion.
3655: Vanishing.text_posted:

Good for combat situations too: even though you can't phase the creature out in response to normal damage anymore, you can still phase it out before damage step entirely, allowing you to block without risk of losing your creature (i.e. the [autocard]Dream Fighter[/autocard] effect).

3656: Vision Charm.author: casual_melvin
3656: Vision Charm.text_parsed:
For reference the land types are:

forest
island
mountain
plains
swamp

desert
gate
lair
locus
mine
power-plant
tower
urza's

All lands that have whichever of the above types you name will have the second typed named instead of all previous types until end of turn. IE if you name mountain for the first type and swamp for the second then a land that has types forest and mountain will gain type swamp and lose its forest and mountain types until end of turn.

Non basic lands that gain basic types are still non-basic lands and still have the same name.

Desert-Forest is my favorite change and seems to fit the flavor of visions.
If it got to keep it's original type then Desert-Island would be neat too.

3657: Waterspout Djinn.author: stygimoloch
3657: Waterspout Djinn.text_parsed: Although this isn't a tremendously strong card on its own, and in most cases better alternatives exist (Air Elemental for a start), it can be a decent mid-to-late game player in some faster blue decks, when the bouncing Island isn't likely to make a whole load of difference. It can return Islands for the likes of Foil, Seismic Assault or Forbid. There's a lot of other very niche applications for that too, from Cursed Scroll to the 'hand size matters' mechanic of Saviours, and as a 4/4 flier for 4, this is worth remembering for decks which may want to abuse such things.

3659: City of Solitude.author: Equinox523
3659: City of Solitude.text_parsed:
One of the most powerful hosers ever printed, and the card that protected delicate combo pieces in decks like Prosperity/Cadaverous Bloom, often considered one of the first true combo decks. It hoses all kinds of things, from countermagic (blue) to instant creature removal (black), which are weaknesses of green. The beauty of it was that you couldn't Disenchant it the turn it dropped either, so your only hope was to counter it. And with black's rich suite of discard, you could play Coercion or the like to make sure you protected your City from countermagic before laying it down.

The art is also fantastic and evocative. It's also a green control card, which is sorely lacking in the game's history. This card gets a 5/5 for me, the perfect mix of subtlety, beauty and utility.

And with black's rich suite of discard, you could play [autocard]Coercion[/autocard] or the like to make sure you protected your City from countermagic before laying it down.

3659: City of Solitude.author: Mode
3659: City of Solitude.text_parsed:
"It stops mana abilities?! So if I have a triggered ability that says 'whenever such and such happens, you may pay 1, and it's not my turn'... I can't..." --KikiJikiTiki

You are mistaken.
A triggered ability and an activated ability are two different things, even if the triggered ability basically offers an option ("may"-clause) that could be considered an activation cost like on Mind's Eye, Cemetry Puka or Ajani's Pridemate.
See for yourself on this very card's ruling notes:
"City of Solitude does not stop triggered abilities from being put on the stack. They are never 'activated'."

Triggered ability always start with words like "When(ever)" or "If"; activated abilities can easily be identified by their colon, with the activation cost left from it and the abilities' effect right from it.
3659: City of Solitude.text_posted:
"[i]It stops mana abilities?! So if I have a triggered ability that says 'whenever such and such happens, you may pay 1, and it's not my turn'... I can't...[/i]" --KikiJikiTiki

You are mistaken.
A triggered ability and an activated ability are two different things, even if the triggered ability basically offers an option ("may"-clause) that could be considered an activation cost like on [autocard]Mind's Eye[/autocard], [autocard]Cemetry Puka[/autocard] or [autocard]Ajani's Pridemate[/autocard].
See for yourself on this very card's ruling notes:
"[i]City of Solitude does [u]not[/u] stop triggered abilities from being put on the stack. They are never 'activated'.[/i]"

Triggered ability always start with words like "[i]When(ever)[/i]" or "[i]If[/i]"; activated abilities can easily be identified by their colon, with the activation cost left from it and the abilities' effect right from it.

3659: City of Solitude.author: syrazemyla

@Mode: KikiJikiTiki meant triggered abilities like the one on Rishadan Cutpurse, which reads "When Rishadan Cutpurse enters the battlefield, each opponent sacrifices a permanent unless he or she pays ." If someone casts Rishadan Cutpurse when City of Solitude is out, none of their opponents will be able to pay unless they have a triggered ability like Mana Echoes, as they can't tap lands for mana.

The strongest card to combo with this strategy is Fade Away, which requires opponents to sacrifice one permanent for every creature they control.

3661: Elephant Grass.author: Salient
3661: Elephant Grass.text_parsed:
Spectacular in multiplayer; great to topdeck this when you're not going first. ": Your opponents can't attack you. You may pay to repeat this effect next turn."

Even outside the Enchantress decks in Legacy, where 4x Grass is standard 'cause they use things like Presence of the Enchantress for card advantage, this is nearly a double Fog. Run four in your Turbo Fog deck, and you'll see how often they save you -- Turbo Fog can die from lack of card advantage, and you can squeak three turns' protection out of this card alone.

Don't get tricked into thinking this is awfully weak in the late-game -- I've taken damage from the "unless they pay " clause, sure, but often enough it still slows the rush for a few turns, so I can draw into my Wrath of God or whatever. It pairs perfectly with Ensnaring Bridge to hold off the single-huge-baddie problem.

3661: Elephant Grass.author: corranhorn84
3661: Elephant Grass.text_parsed:
After reading several comments, it seems some either don't understand or are misinterpreting what "cumulative" means.

From the MTG rulebook:

702.22. Cumulative Upkeep

702.22a. Cumulative upkeep is a triggered ability that imposes an increasing cost on a permanent. Cumulative upkeep 'cost' means At the beginning of your upkeep, put an age counter on this permanent. Then you may pay 'cost' for each age counter on it. If you dont, sacrifice it. If 'cost' has choices associated with it, each choice is made separately for each age counter, then either the entire set of costs is paid, or none of them is paid. Partial payments arent allowed.

If 'cost' has choices associated with it, each choice is made separately for each age counter, then either the entire set of costs is paid, or none of them is paid. Partial payments arent allowed.

3666: Katabatic Winds.author: Kirbster
3666: Katabatic Winds.text_parsed: This card gets help from its usefulness being a result of it just being in play. No phasing creatures have haste, so they show up, wait for a turn, then phase out, wait another turn, and finally on their third turn can attack. By that point they're behind the curve, even if they were big for their mana cost three turns ago! The Winds, meanwhile, will keep flyers from doing anything the moment it's down. It can make your opponent unable to block when you play it or counterattack on his or her turn, which is in itself decent for three mana.

3670: Mortal Wound.author: DrJack
3670: Mortal Wound.text_parsed:
Why did you guys give this 2 1/2 stars, while Mire Blight (black carbon-copy of this) got 3 1/2?

Green needs creature removal far more than black - which has a billion creature killers already, many of which are overpowered (Doom blade, anyone?) Mortal Wound is pretty nice. Just a single mana, and the next time your opponent's creature blocks or is blocked, it's gone. Has nice synergy with Prodigal Sorcerer, Pestilence, D'Avenant Archer, and basically anything reusable so you don't lose card advantage. In some cases a Hurricane or Sandstorm works well with it, where it's dealing with other creatures/players at the same time.

Strike fear into your opponent with Mortal Wound. 3.5 out of 5.

3671: Natural Order.author: Haelthor
3671: Natural Order.text_parsed: I don't know how long this card has been in my/family's collection but I'm so glad it is. It's currently in my Damia, Sage of Stone commander deck and it's always beastly. If someone else is playing blue I always tell them that they do NOT want this spell to resolve. My common targets are Woodfall Primus, Terastodon, but above all: Vorinclex. Getting Big V on turn 3 (with mana available for Lightning Greaves) is very possible and guaranteed to drop the jaws of everyone at the table. Typically, though, I'll play Natural Order saccing a Fauna Shaman after she's done a bit of work tutoring different creatures for me to abuse the extra mana with. This card, Tooth and Nail, and Rite of Replication are all good reasons to run a copy Boseiju in your commander deck; more often than not, I just wait until the counterspell players are tapped out from dealing with everyone else then I drop this and grin. This is an absurdly powerful card.

3671: Natural Order.author: Zeofar
3671: Natural Order.text_parsed:
Actually, the flavor text is the end of the story which is begun in Relic Ward's flavor text. Read together, they form the following sentence:

"Asmira's prayers alone should have freed Mangara from the amber prison . . . but the price of Mangara's freedom was Asmira's life."

The described scene is a central event in the Mirage block storyline. Mangara came to rule Zhalfir, Femeref, and Suq'Ata after bringing peace to Jumaraa. However, he was betrayed by Kaervek, who trapped him in the Amber Prison. Asmira eventually freed Mangara from the prison, but was slain by Purraj, an ally of Kaervek, in the process. Mangara defeated Kaervek by trapping him in the prison afterward.

Actually, the flavor text [i]is[/i] the end of the story which is begun in [autocard]Relic Ward[/autocard]'s flavor text. Read together, they form the following sentence:

3674: Quirion Ranger.author: Kirbster
3674: Quirion Ranger.text_parsed:
You can get an amazing amount of utility out of this innocuous li'l lady.

For one, she can provide an extra mana on turns where you haven't played a land. You can tap all your forests for mana, bounce one with her, then replay it and tap for one more. If she's untapping something like a Llanowar Elves, though... that's even more mana. With a mana elf to help, she can help you pull five mana out of two lands!

That's thinking small, though. She gets absolutely ridiculous with something like Rofellos, Llanowar Emissary or Priest of Titania. Let's also not forget powerful utility creatures like Ulvenwald Tracker and Elvish Piper!

That's just keeping in green, mind you. You can get all sorts of bad craziness if you're playing multiple colours. Imagine, all of this potential from a 1-drop made to combat Stasis!

3685: Elkin Lair.author: scumbling1
3685: Elkin Lair.text_parsed:
It's not a strong card, but I kinda like it. It's a very subtle hoser for any sort of reactive control decks; it reminds me of Uba Mask in several ways. It's nice to see some sort of depth in Red, as I think it doesn't have to be the "dumb" color. So an alternative to the usual words "damage" and "destroy" is often welcome.

They could have safely shaved two mana off the card, though. Oh well.

It's nice to see some sort of depth in Red, as I think it doesn't have to be the "dumb" color. So an alternative to the usual words "damage" and "destroy" is often welcome.

They could have safely shaved two mana off the card, though. Oh well.

3686: Fireblast.author: Equinox523
3686: Fireblast.text_parsed: One of the premier burn spells of all time.  The fact that it can be played when tapped out to instantly kill a creature, or to push through a few extra points of damage, makes it a powerful weapon in mono-red decks (and also a reason to use basic lands).  It exemplifies Red's philosophy of throwing caution to the wind, in favor of a quick and sudden strike.  In modern Magic, with all of its reliance on non-basic lands and multi-color scheming, I hope that we will see more cards like this appear once in a while to remind us of what mono-red burn is all about.

Turn 1 Nomads en-Kor

@Chamale

It doesn't work the way the card is worded now, but the original Tempest wording of Furnace of Rath doubled damage assigned to any creature or player, regardless of whether the damage would actually be dealt. I suspect that en-Kor damage bouncing is a part of the reason they changed it, actually.

When you're a burn staple in legacy, you know you're doing something right.

Fact is 3 for a card is good. 4 for a card is great. 4 for 0-mana is excellent.

T1 - 3 damage card. (Bolt, Rift bolt, whatever..)
T2 - Keldon Marauders for 1
T3 - Burn + Hellspark + marauders for 9
T4 - This + maruaders for 5. Any other 2+ damage burn for the win.

And that's before considering Fetches, shocks, and other pay life effects.

3690: Heat Wave.author: yyukichigai
3690: Heat Wave.text_parsed:
It's a lot pricier than its compatriot Elephant Grass, but the effect is really something. If you can keep this in play for just a few turns while you attack with some persistent attackers it can really help wear someone down. With 1/1 creatures in particular it gets very painful, since every block costs them just as much life as if they hadn't blocked.

This card has won me games on multiple occasions. It's only powerful in the right deck, but in that deck it's amazing.

3696: Ogre Enforcer.author: GrimjawxRULES
3696: Ogre Enforcer.text_parsed:
@ bhunji:
I agree, the oracle text of this is very confusing, and I myself find the original wording easier to understand.
For people who doesn't understand what this card does, basically, it can't be destroyed by lethal damage if more than one source assigns damage to it. Example: Ogre Enforcer won't die if I burn it with 2 Lightning Bolts, but it will die if I burn it with a Flame Javelin. Likewise, casting 2 copies of Pyroclasm won't kill it, and if Ogre Enforcer is blocked by a 3/2 and a 2/1 creature, it will survive through combat.

Overall, this card seems pretty decent, though nowhere near tournament level, I can imagine some odd plays made with this.
3696: Ogre Enforcer.text_posted:
@ bhunji:
I agree, the oracle text of this is very confusing, and I myself find the original wording easier to understand.
For people who doesn't understand what this card does, basically, it can't be destroyed by lethal damage if more than one source assigns damage to it. Example: Ogre Enforcer won't die if I burn it with 2 [autocard]Lightning Bolt[/autocard]s, but it will die if I burn it with a [autocard]Flame Javelin[/autocard]. Likewise, casting 2 copies of [autocard]Pyroclasm[/autocard] won't kill it, and if Ogre Enforcer is blocked by a 3/2 and a 2/1 creature, it will survive through combat.

Overall, this card seems pretty decent, though nowhere near tournament level, I can imagine some odd plays made with this.

3696: Ogre Enforcer.author: deggdegg
3696: Ogre Enforcer.text_parsed:
@bhunji42:

I don't think the card makes sense as printed. No creature can be destroyed unless a single source deals enough damage to destroy it. If I have a regular 4/4 creature, and you Lightning Bolt it twice, the second Lightning Bolt surely does enough damage to destroy it, right? However, as per the Oracle wording, this guy would have 3 damage from LB1 and 3 damage form LB2 marked on him, neither of which is lethal, so he's not destroyed.

3696: Ogre Enforcer.author: deworde2510
3696: Ogre Enforcer.text_parsed: For those wondering, the reason they change the Oracle text is because while the text as written reads better, from a purely mathematical perspective, it doesn't work in the rules. Specifically when it interacts with damage prevention or damage removal, without a clear in-rules way of dealing with it, you can't specify what would happen without room for argument. Which in the unlikely event of this deciding if you top 8 or not, could mean thousands of pounds to you.

3696: Ogre Enforcer.author: Wraique
3696: Ogre Enforcer.text_parsed:
@majinara

Enforcer works no better with Pyrohemia than any other 4-toughness creature. The source of the damage is the enchantment, not the effect on the stack. Splitting a source's damage into separate effects would likewise result in the ogre being destroyed as all the resulting damage marked on the ogre would have come from a single source (activating Pyrohemia 4 times still marks 4 damage on the ogre, all damage dealt by Pyrohemia). Two Pyrohemias or more are a different kettle of bananas though. You could really have some fun there :)

I love this card's effect, and I want to marry it. State-based actions be damned!

3704: Talruum Champion.author: Aquillion
3704: Talruum Champion.text_parsed:
@SengirPatriarch: It doesn't interact with double strike at all. It only removes first strike, which they don't have.

Against a double strike creature, both this card and the double-striker will do damage at the same time, in the first strike step; and then (if it's still alive) the double striker will do a second iteration of damage in the 'normal' step.

Anyway, this card is mostly terrible. First Strike is a somewhat rare and situational ability in the first place; it's not worth paying so much extra to interact with it.

3704: Talruum Champion.author: NobuTheBard
3704: Talruum Champion.text_parsed:
If anyone reading this later wasn't aware; this card was inspired by the old Throat Wolf Usenet rumor. It was allegedly an "ultra-rare" card that had the ability "firstest strike" or "firster strike".

I think the rumor specified it was green? I didn't read Usenet back then, I only heard the rumor indirectly, and at the time thought it was entirely plausible (which says a lot about me, heh). In any case, an "actual" Throat Wolf appeared in Duelist Magazine as a fake joke card. If you're curious you can find it out there on the internet.

3705: Talruum Piper.author: Mr_Hendry
3705: Talruum Piper.text_parsed:
I give this card 4 stars not because it's especially useful in most situations but because in constructed it's a very unusual ability for red. With the exception of Mortipede (goofy name) and Nemesis Mask all cards with the Lure ability are green. Even Mortipede has a green activation cost for its lure ability. This card has the caveat that the lured creature must be flying which perhaps makes it more true to the color but not much.

Also you got to love the whole quirky Minotaurs playing Didgeridoo thing. Who came up with that!?

3707: Viashino Sandstalker.author: humor_love
3707: Viashino Sandstalker.text_parsed:
One of my favorite red cards. Plays out much better than it looks. For one thing, it keeps your hand size up. Once played, opponents know that it's in your hand, but playing this means you can keep hold of the other cards you have - and those cards generally remain unknown. Hard to describe. One of those cards you have to play to feel.

Look at it this way: If Unearth is thought to be a useful ability (see Hellspark Elemental), this card is better.

3710: Equipoise.author: mrredhatter
3710: Equipoise.text_parsed: Run with Sands of Time.

3710: Equipoise.author: Ragamander
3710: Equipoise.text_parsed:
Edit @Lateralis0ne: Phasing-in happens during the untap step, which is skipped due to Sands of Time. It is permanent.

Sands of Time works okay, but it's really most effective as a comeback combo, since it ends up functioning much like Balance. I'm convinced there has to be some utterly ridiculous combo with this card. Maybe add Greater Gargadon to the mix? Suspend the Gargadon, and, later, at the beginning of your upkeep, with Equipoise and Sands of Time on the table, sacrifice your non-enchantment, non-planeswalker, non-Sands of Time permanents until the Gargadon has one counter left (hopefully this is all your non-Sands of Time permanents). Equipoise resolves, then the Gargadon loses its last counter and comes into play. Then you hit them in their defenseless, vulnerable face with the Gargadon a few times.


T1: Play a mountain; suspend Gargadon.
T2: Gargadon goes to 9 counters; play a plains; play Raise the Alarm/Dragon Fodder.
T3: Gargadon goes to 8 counters; play a land; play Equipoise.
T4: Gargadon goes to 7 counters; play a land; play Sands of Time.
T5: Sacrifice all lands and all creatures to the Gargadon (goes to 1); resolve Equipoise (all but one artifact phases out permanently); Gargadon goes to 0 counters; Gargadon comes into play; the beatdown begins.


Yeah, that seems pretty ridiculous. Time for me to go make the deck.

3710: Equipoise.author: Lateralis0ne
3710: Equipoise.text_parsed:
Hold on, Ragamander, they wouldn't phase out permanently. Sure, every time your turn rolls around, all of their stuff would phase out, but it phases back in before each of their untap steps once your turn ends. Thus, their permanents don't suffer summoning sickness, and they can go on to bash the hell out of you on their own turn.

This works more as a reverse bottled cloister, affecting your opponent on your turn. Yours is a good idea, but it does have its holes.

Edit: @Ragamander, alright, I see. I just read "before untapping", not "before untapping durin the untap step". So yes, you're right; this works wonders with Sands of Time, my apologies.

Though, at 7 mana, you better be able to keep your board presence minimal as often as possible. Greater Gargadon is a great suggestion from Ragamander, and I'm sure in a white red aggro/control deck this could work wonders. Setting up the lock ({7}{W}) could be a bit pricy, but in Vintage, anything is possible.

I love this card so much. Oh, so you're playing a multicolored deck? Hope you're just fixing with fetchlands and basics... ^_^

Goes very well teamed up with blue for Clone-type love. Dance of the Many, Rite of Replication, Phantasmal Image, Phyrexian Metamorph, Clone itself, all that jazz - you get cheap Terrors, and get to keep the copy to boot.

Vesuva also becomes nonbasic land destruction. =P

3711: Eye of Singularity.author: Ragamander

If you want to get multiples onto the field (like by casting Conqueror's Pledge), just use Sundial of the Infinite to skip resolving the trigger.

Also great with Hunted Phantasm, Hunted Horror, Hunted Dragon, and Hunted Troll.

Also fun if you're running multiples of indestructible creatures.

3712: Freewind Falcon.author: MattLynn
3712: Freewind Falcon.text_parsed:
When I began playing over fifteen years ago, this was a key part to the Soraya, the Falconeer kitchen table deck. That was pre-"Grand Creature Type Update." Not too bad, even storm crow can be bolted, but not this flyer. Of course, there was Terror back then, too, but nobody bothered because there was always juicier targets. I forgot the pro-black one...Dusk-something Falcon. Was more splash able than knights...that's about it. Of course, the Soltari knocked protection & evasion out of the park soon after this...

Got to remember this was even before Tempest Block.

3715: Hope Charm.author: Salient
3715: Hope Charm.text_parsed:
The Vision charms were designed to experiment with modality. This is one of those cards that isn't important because it's good or nostalgic -- it's important because it let Wizards' R&D department grow comfortable with spells that allow you to make choices.

Still, three stars seems a bit high for a so-so card that never saw constructed play in any format at any time.

3720: Miraculous Recovery.author: mrredhatter
3720: Miraculous Recovery.text_parsed: Better than Breath of Life if you intend to exploit the instant mechanic.

3720: Miraculous Recovery.author: ClockworkSwordfish
3720: Miraculous Recovery.text_parsed: White's answer to Vigor Mortis, but this is more splashable than that. The Elephant token in the room, however, is that this is an instant, not a sorcery. This makes it exponentially more fun and well worth the extra manum (Singular of mana?). For example, my opponent attacked with a pumped-up, enchanted 14/14 shade when I had about 5 life and only a Tireless Tribe. After declare attackers, he Terrored the Tribe. In response, I discarded a Phytohydra, then it immediately made a Miraculous Recovery just in time to block. Then I played Double Cleave on HIS shade. The shade died and I had almost a 30/30 on hand to attack on my turn. Game over. Try having that much fun with Breath of Life.
3720: Miraculous Recovery.text_posted: White's answer to [autocard]Vigor Mortis[/autocard], but this is more splashable than that. 3720: Miraculous Recovery.author: kiseki
3720: Miraculous Recovery.text_parsed:
This card is a blast. I love flexible white cards that let you pass the turn with your mana untapped.
It is especially fun with "enters the battlefield" effects to make it even more efficient. Glimmerpoint Stag for instance allows you to have an instant speed answer to almost any permanent that leaves a 3/3 vigilance on the field afterwards. And both of these cards combo with all the other ETB creatures you put in the deck.

3721: Parapet.author: djbon2112
3721: Parapet.text_parsed: @Horsemanship The last step of the turn, when you discard down to your max hand size and such. Basically, read the original wording; that's how it works, except saccing it is the last thing you do before discarding. Too bad, this little ability had some potential for cool effects. Also, "substance" only existed for a short while, and was a MTGO hack to allow these cards to work properly when Mirage/Visions went to MTGO; the problem was, these would go away before damage was cleaned off creatures, causing them to fail functionally; that wasn't a problem IRL since people just got what they were supposed to do, but under the current rules, it didn't technically work like that, and since MTGO has to be perfect rules-wise, it was a conundrum. The substance ability has since been removed and this card works how it once did, but requires clunkier rules text to accomplish it.

3727: Righteous Aura.author: majinara
3727: Righteous Aura.text_parsed:
@ ideatog: that's because back in the days people played all this effects as lasting only until end of turn.
Look at an old version of fog: it says "nothing until end of turn", yet noone assume that a fog would prevent any combat damage dealt forever.
Or blessing: it didn't say "until end of turn" either, yet it was played that way.

Righteous Aura works and always worked the same way.

Edit: And the aura is pretty awesome, especially in multiplayer decks. It prevents damage from creatures with shroud or protection. It also prevents damage from sorceries, all kinds of abilities. Not to mention that it can even be useful on creatures with two or less power, since it prevents any abilities they might have that trigger on combat damage from doing so.

3729: Teferi's Honor Guard.author: Mainstay
3729: Teferi's Honor Guard.text_parsed:
Vastly underrated, even if it isn't at the height of its power. When it debuted, it was an unparalleled defender in its colors, and one of only a few critters capable of surviving a Wrath of God. If you had the mana up, it was almost impossible to kill. That's still true, even with today's wide selection of removal possibilities.

Auras attached to it phase out with it, making it a great Voltron chassis. The flanking doesn't do much, but it does let it block creatures with multiple instances of flanking that would otherwise kill it before its ability could be put on the stack. EDIT: No, that's wrong, flanking is triggered, not state-based. But hey, it's not like flanking is a *disadvantage*...

When the rules changed for a while, and damage went on the stack, it might as well have been unblockable by creatures with a toughness of three or less. But even without that craziness, this card should be up in the fours, instead of a lowly 3.4.

3734: Breathstealer's Crypt.author: Ragamander
3734: Breathstealer's Crypt.text_parsed:
Why not just play this in a deck that doesn't run many creatures?

Damnation, Black Sun's Zenith, and Mutilate can keep you alive while, in combination with Breathstealer's Crypt, forcing your opponent to take damage in order to rebuild their board presence. Heck, you could even use cards like Vanishment and Spin into Myth to harass your opponent; Misinformation also becomes amusing. And don't get me started on Agonizing Memories; it's brutal enough on its own.

If you are especially sadistic, why not also play Time Spiral/Time Reversal and/or Wheel of Fortune/Reforge the Soul? You get a new hand of kill spells and countermagic, while they aren't left with much of a hand unless they sacrifice large amounts of life. For an added dose of silly, Teferi's Puzzle Box will punish them even more after forcing them to redraw a hand of seven.

Failing that, why not run reanimation spells and/or Madness creatures, as others have mentioned? Or you could go for the kill with Spiteful Visions and maybe Words of War to prevent you from accidentally killing yourself, with the added bonus of helping to kill your opponent?

Also mentioned before, Megrim and Liliana's Caress put your opponent in a Catch-22 situation. Shrieking Affliction can also punish opponents who keep discarding their creatures.


This is an awesome card, from a design and gameplay perspective. I think cards like this are healthy for Magic: The Gathering. My only complaint, really, is that it's maybe overcosted by . would curve into the black board sweepers much more elegantly.

3736: Femeref Enchantress.author: Mode
3736: Femeref Enchantress.text_parsed:
So far the only enchantress that triggers the carddraw not when casting it, but with a put-into-graveyard/"pig" effect instead.
This makes her a great choice if you're going to use Enchantments that return themselves when they (or the creature they are enchanting) is put into a graveyard.
Possible choices are the aforementioned Rancor, the Genju Land Aura cycle, Aspect of the Mongoose, Spirit Loop, or Spreading Algae.
Some Auras will even directly return to the battlefield, most notably Screams from Within, which will allow you to draw a card for each of your opponent's x/1 creature hosed.
Reins of the Veinsteed is more useful for your own creatures, and the Dragon Auras also return directly.
Enchantments which have an inherent ability that allows saccing them might of course be useful as well.

And another card that turned from playable to total garbage thanks to the M10 rules change.

Before M10 your opponent had to choose: does he want to get mana burned or grant you mana instead? Now, the only thing this hippo does is tap all your opponents lands, since they can simply tap everything in response to this hippos ability. :(

From 4/5 down to 2/5.

3740: Pygmy Hippo.author: Tanaka348
3740: Pygmy Hippo.text_parsed: That's somewhat incorrect. Pygmy Hippo drains all mana from the opponent's mana pool, even if it wasn't put there by the first part of the ability. 3740: Pygmy Hippo.author: Piedmont
3740: Pygmy Hippo.text_parsed:
I just love this card, its a hippo and I just love the photo the hippo looks so shiny and proud. As mentioned Favor of the overbeing is a good combo for some real fun.

I agree M10 rules makes it is not as useful (they can tap their lands during the declare attackers step to make sure you don't get any mana), but there was an interesting situation that did come up online while I was attacking with him. During the declare blockers step they swords to plowshares so they would have mana afterward... and at the end of combat Magic online forced them to tap all their lands and I got the mana. If you read the situation above carefully the pygmy hippo attacked, no blockers were declared (instead he was plowshared), his ability still triggered. The other person learned afterward next time, to have something block it and THEN swords it :)

It's just a fun card, 4/5.

3740: Pygmy Hippo.author: Justice1337
3740: Pygmy Hippo.text_parsed:
On how the mana burn change impacted this card -

Sure, it sort of used to be something of a Wilderness Elemental with mana burn. But, it was always sort of this straight beef kind of card. Your opponent could always just tap their land to avoid the drain, if that's what position they were in. But, what's a few damage? That's not why this card would be played over Tarmogoyf.

Everything it used to do, it still does. A cheaper Dosan the Falling Leaf, making you mostly immune to everything your opponent would want to cast on your turn. It's one half of a Nature's Will on a stick, which is just what you want in a deck with Winter Orb and similar effects.

Still a very solid card, one with an effect that we rarely see.
3740: Pygmy Hippo.text_posted:

Your opponent could always just tap their land to avoid the drain, if that's what position they were in.  But, what's a few damage?  That's not why this card would be played over Tarmogoyf.

Everything it used to do, it still does.  A cheaper [card]Dosan the Falling Leaf[/card], making you mostly immune to everything your opponent would want to cast on your turn.  It's one half of a [c]Nature's Will[/c] on a stick, which is just what you want in a deck with [card]Winter Orb[/card] and similar effects.

Still a very solid card, one with an effect that we rarely see.

3741: Righteous War.author: CeremonialBathory
3741: Righteous War.text_parsed: @infernox10 - Remember D.E.B.T. Righteous War doesn't damage, enchant, block or target the creatures. Don't get confused because it's an enchantment. Without being an Enchantment - Aura it doesn't actively enchant any one creature. It simply gives all your white creatures pro-black and all your black creature pro-white. It doesn't say it enchants a creature or that it targets them in the text so it gets around its own protection ability.
3741: Righteous War.text_posted: @infernox10 - Remember D.E.B.T. Righteous War doesn't damage, enchant, block or target the creatures. Don't get confused because it's an enchantment. It doesn't say it enchants a creature or that it targets them in the text so it gets around its own protection ability.
