3747: Viashivan Dragon.author: OpenSeasonNoobs
3747: Viashivan Dragon.text_parsed:
Pumping toughness is always going to be just a mana drain. It's not going to help you 9 times out of 10. You'll end up sinking more mana into a card that is already only a so-so card.

Peruse the following: Would you normally spend 6 mana to play a 4/4 creature with flying? Let's also remember that 4 of that mana is specific.. Which normally makes a card BETTER not still a PoS. Firebreathing is always nice, but you want it on something that is going to either not be blocked, or something cheap to throw it and remove another creature with it.

Anyway, if you're willing to mana fix for this card, consider the other dragons for 6 mana that have red and green mana costs. Rith, the Awakener Intet, the dreamer. 1/5

3747: Viashivan Dragon.author: Technetium
3747: Viashivan Dragon.text_parsed:
This is really not that good, for several reasons. Consider the comparison with the Shivan Dragon:
1. Each ability will only be half as effective as the Shivan Dragon's, assuming you have the same total number of land in play. Therefore, on abilities they should be considered even.
2. For each additional color, a creature should either gain power or reduce the CMC. This card has reduced P/T from Shivan Dragon, and requires 4 specific mana instead of two, with the same CMC.

It should have cost 3RG, or RRGG, and been 5/5.

3748: Coral Atoll.author: DarthParallax
3748: Coral Atoll.text_parsed:
I wouldn't say Obsoleted: these are effectively equal to Ravnica Bounce lands if you are playing EDH and your Commander only produces one of the two Colors.

Every 3 Color Commander can probably over look these, since I would doubt you actually need SIX Bounce lands, but 2 Color Commanders can be happy playing these because the requirement to have a Basic Land type is easier when you are running few colors.

Sure, Alpha and Ravnica Dual Lands have types, and there's the Fetches, but even so, a straight Green-Blue deck probably sees only a marginal difference in card quality comparing this to Simic Growth Chamber. If you can afford to run more Basics, and you have cards that work fine with your basic lands, why not?

And for MONO-colored Commander decks, these actually become better because...well, on the one hand they do the exact same thing as Bounce lands from Ravnica, on the other hand you don't have to actually remember anything to know that. =)

3748: Coral Atoll.author: Kirbster
3748: Coral Atoll.text_parsed:
The thing that really holds these lands back is that they have to bounce an untapped basic land. The Ravnica bounce lands make two coloured mana - meaning the other one can be used for colourless anyway - and can bounce any land, even if it's tapped. That means you can tap all of your lands for mana before bouncing one, whereas playing a Karoo land will always cost you one mana the turn you do it.

Still, they aren't awful. And they all have great art!
3748: Coral Atoll.text_posted:
The thing that really holds these lands back is that they have to bounce an [i]untapped[/i] basic land. The Ravnica bounce lands make two coloured mana - meaning the other one can be used for colourless anyway - and can bounce any land, even if it's tapped. That means you can tap all of your lands for mana before bouncing one, whereas playing a Karoo land will always cost you one mana the turn you do it.

Still, they aren't awful. And they all have great art!

3751: Griffin Canyon.author: yyukichigai
3751: Griffin Canyon.text_parsed:
I find this card maddening. It goes great in any Griffin deck, except Griffins in general are overcosted to the point where they're not readily playable. Even when this card first came out the cheapest Griffin you could find was {3}{W}, which makes me wonder why it and Zuberi, Golden Feather were printed. To make us wish Griffins could be cool?

It's a little less difficult to make a Griffin deck now, what with Azorius First-Wing, Fledgling Griffin, Wild Griffin, Diving Griffin, and even Tethered Griffin, but it's still not an easy thing.
3751: Griffin Canyon.text_posted:

3753: Karoo.author: GradiustheFox
3753: Karoo.text_parsed: Well at least it doesn't eat your Life, deplete your hand, or defile your daughter like most "special" lands.  Compared to many its demands are fairly reasonable.  Worth playing if you don't have any other lands in your hand and know you're not getting one next turn...  It's an investment that pays off quickly enough, but I'm sure there are much better ways to get extra mana.  PS - I certainly didn't.  Is it a nice place?

3753: Karoo.text_parsed: I never cared much for these lands - they're not that different in the long run from basics, and a liability in the short term. 3754: Quicksand.author: CLU10123
3754: Quicksand.text_parsed: This is a nice trick, but I would really only see myself playing this on turn one though.  I mean you can really only use this against the aggro decks that want to get you to 10 life on turn three. This is legal in standard at the moment( as of June 2011), and I don't know why people aren't playing this. It is looks useful against the decks that use aggro staples like Goblin guide, but yet again you can't really see this being played against a deck like Cawblade. I good card all around.

its a really good gold land for the third spot in led dredge but at the same time Cephalid coliseum is usually used instead of it for the hope of more explosive starts. its perfect for the Sharuum build in led dredge because you recur lions eye diamonds instead of using coliseum most of the time. only problem iv have ran into is getting two in my opening hand so i cut it down to 3.

the 3rd gold land that dredge needs is this.

{t}: add one mana of any color to your mana pool. use this mana only to cast spells or activate abilities with converted mana cost 3 or less.
